In thiscase, policy cou'd be given credit for allowing the money supply to expandrelative to normal.15. The data are from Friedman and Schwartz 11963, Table B—3, pp. 799—808).16. The data are from Chandler (1970. p. 162).17. The U.S. also ran a small current account surplus in every year except1936 (see Bloomfield [1950, p. 269)).18. The commercial paper rate data are from the Federal Reserve Board (1943,pp. 448—451 and 1976, p. 674]. They cover 4 to 6 month prime commercial paperand are not seasonally adjusted.19. The historical data on the Producer Price Index are from the Bureau ofLabor Statistics. They are not seasonally adjusted.20. Some of the inflation in 1933 and 1934 could have been due to the NIRA,which encouraged collusion aimed at raising prices, rather than to monetarypolicy.
